At this moment, the nation is still in shock over the barbaric murder of a man beloved by millions. The depth of this tragedy is hard to process: a life cut short at age 31, a wife left without a husband, two young children without a father.

The tributes that have poured in these last 24 hours from people of all walks of life and all corners of the political universe – the raw grief, the remarkable eulogies – bear testament to a life of generational importance, a life cruelly limited in years but immeasurable in impact.

I offer my own most heartfelt prayers alongside the hundreds of millions of others in this country and around the world. As we pray for Charlie and his loved ones, so too do I pray for our country. 

We are in a perilous moment. We don’t yet have all the facts about yesterday’s horrifying events – and the killer remains at large. What we do know is that political division has continued to deepen in this country and that political violence is on the rise.

With a loss this profound, with evil this glaring, with so much pain and suffering and anger and fear – this cycle could escalate. But that isn’t where things have to go. This can also be an occasion for soul-searching as a country. 

A simple thing we can all do: if you have a friend or family member who you have stopped talking to because of political differences, this might be a good time to reach out. To say, we’re still friends, we’re still family. Politics isn’t everything. And politics itself, when properly conducted, can foster friendship and build community even among ideological opponents.

That’s what Charlie Kirk devoted his life to. He brought people of all perspectives together to talk to one another. To have a vigorous exchange of ideas. To discuss how we can best fulfill America’s promise. To participate in democracy.

At this moment, working to rediscover the capacity for unity is a matter of the highest urgency to America's future.

Today, we remember the lives lost on 9/11, the heroes who responded, and the families forever changed.

Let's all take a moment today to honor their memory. 

We will never forget. 🇺🇸 #NeverForget https://t.co/GLGtwV4JYX

I am introducing legislation in Congress to stop Newsom's corrupt scheme to overthrow our Citizens Redistricting Commission and seize its powers for himself.  

My bill prohibits congressional districts from being redrawn in the middle of the decade. This is already the law in California under our State Constitution, which provides that redistricting is done once a decade by an Independent Commission. But Newsom is planning to blow all of this up so he can impose his own partisan map on voters before the next election. 

Fortunately, Congress has the ability to protect California voters using its authority under the Elections Clause of the U.S. Constitution. This will also stop a damaging redistricting war from breaking out across the country.

Californians will soon get something long overdue: major tax relief. That is the most immediate consequence of passing today's legislation, which will benefit all Americans but especially Californians, because of an increase in the SALT deduction.

The bill also provides crucial support for education, national defense, and border security. And it protects our public lands and rural hospitals, both of which I advocated for throughout the legislative process.

In the last year I set out to reverse 10 of Governor Newsom's most harmful policies. We've made significant progress:

1) Gas-Car Ban: My Resolution to reverse the ban passed the House and Senate with bipartisan support.

2) Illegal Health Care: We forced Newsom to end his free Medi-Cal for illegal immigrants policy.

3) Out-of-Control Crime: Our initiative to make crime illegal again, Prop. 36, was passed overwhelmingly by California voters.

4) Homelessness: The Supreme Court ruled in our favor and against Newsom, reversing the 9th Circuit and allowing local communities to clear encampments.

5) High-Speed Rail: The federal government is cutting off funding after the Department of Transportation audit, which we announced in February, found California woefully out of compliance.

6) Sanctuary State: My bill to end sanctuary policies has significant traction, and the combination of executive actions and federal law enforcement has mitigated the sanctuary policy.

7) Water Scarcity: We've secured major funding for the first new significant water storage in California in decades, and we're stopping the diversion of water to the ocean.

8) Catastrophic wildfires: We've passed the Fix Our Forests Act through the House with bipartisan support.

9) Failing Schools: The House just passed the most significant school choice legislation in history, which I sponsored. It is part of the reconciliation bill that will receive a vote in the Senate.

10) Election Chaos: The SAVE Act, a bill I've sponsored to require proof of citizenship to register to vote, has passed the House with bipartisan support.

Today I introduced the Modern Worker Empowerment Act (MWEA) and the Modern Worker Security Act (MWSA) to protect independent workers and businesses from regulatory uncertainty. The MWEA amends existing labor laws to establish a clear and predictable test for determining whether a worker is classified as an independent contractor or an employee. The MWSA establishes a federal safe harbor that allows companies to voluntarily provide portable benefits to independent contractors without the risk of federal agencies reclassifying those workers as employees. Last week I visited Oakmont of Roseville Senior Assisted Living Facility to speak with and take questions from residents. We discussed ways to protect seniors and my commitment in Congress to protecting Social Security & Medicare. I will always vote to keep our promises to our seniors by protecting Social Security and Medicare.

It has been one year since the October 7 terrorist attacks by Hamas. The monstrous acts committed that day against innocent men, women, and children remain difficult to fathom. One year later Israel continues to struggle with the magnitude of this loss and the further losses suffered in defending itself, while also facing unprecedented threats to its very existence.

As we remember those who were killed, and as we renew our resolve to bring home those who remain hostage, it is more important than ever that America stand with our ally Israel in a unified, unwavering, and bipartisan way.

The Fire Safe Council of Nevada County has received a $7.8 million grant from FEMA. The funds will go towards a project to provide a critical protection zone to the communities of Grass Valley, Nevada City and Penn Valley all of which are at risk of fire in the Deer Creek drainage. Phase one will involve public outreach, home hardening and defensible space assessments, and parcel prescriptions for hazardous fuels reduction. https://t.co/17wmnkwQIr
